pullRequest.body:
Updates `Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.Simultaneous.lean` from the pairwise to the finite tuple case: i.e. gives decomposition of finite-dimensional Hilbert space as internal direct sum of joint eigenspaces of a commuting tuple of symmetric operators.

Co-Authored by: Jack Cheverton <jt18chev@siena.edu>

Co-Authored by: Samyak Dhar Tuladhar <sd10tula@siena.edu>

---

- [x] depends on: #18054

üöÄ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by j-loreaux.

> Thanks for this.
> 
> I have some concerns about whether these results are being developed at the right level of generality. I have highlighted two results which work for any generalised eigenspace, not just the strict eigenspace (`k = 1` case). I am also a bit surprised that my changes proposed in #16915 have not been implemented (even though that PR was closed on this promise üò±)
> 
> I also wonder what other results might be split out which are true for coefficients other than `‚Ñù` or `‚ÑÇ`.
> 
> Unfortunately I don't have more time to give to this at the moment but I encourage you to think carefully about these points: it's sometimes a lot more work but I think we all benefit hugely from working more generally where this is possible.

I will think carefully about these, @ocfnash. Just for the record, I actually thought I *had* incorporated the suggestions from #16915 by changing the top two results to work over a `CommRing`. Evidently, I did not see this as clearly as I thought I had. Sorry! It seems like most of the orthogonality results required `RCLike`. Maybe the idea for generalizing is to remove the use of the orthogonality as much as possible.

Thanks for all your great work on this @JonBannon I really appreciate that you're sticking with it and I know very well that it can be tough going when working in a corner of the library that is less familiar.

I had very little time this morning so I'm going to take a closer look now and see if I can be more helpful.

I thought a little more about this and here are my thoughts.

1. I'd probably first prove the result that for symmetric operators, (maximal) generalised eigenspaces and true eigenspaces are the same thing.

2. I claim it is usually better to work within the lattice of submodules and so I think rather than proving a headline result in the language of `DirectSum.IsInternal` I'd prove the equivalent pair of conditions according to [DirectSum.isInternal_submodule_iff_independent_and_iSup_eq_top](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/DirectSum/Module.html#DirectSum.isInternal_submodule_iff_independent_and_iSup_eq_top) [Feel free to disagree with me here; I mention this primarily because I use this language below]

3. I think the right level of generality is to prove the following first:
```lean
open Module in
lemma iSup_iInf_maxGenEigenspace_eq_top_of_commute {Œπ K V : Type*}
    [Field K] [AddCommGroup V] [Module K V] [FiniteDimensional K V]
    (f : Œπ ‚Üí End K V)
    (h : Pairwise fun i j ‚Ü¶ Commute (f i) (f j))
    (h' : ‚àÄ i, ‚®Ü Œº, (f i).maxGenEigenspace Œº = ‚ä§) :
    ‚®Ü œá : Œπ ‚Üí K, ‚®Ö i, (f i).maxGenEigenspace (œá i) = ‚ä§ := by
sorry
```
(and a similar statement for independence)

4. Assuming I've got the above right, combining 1 and 3 should give you what you need for symmetric operators in the more restrictive setting of an `InnerProductSpace` (with coeffs in `‚Ñù` or `‚ÑÇ`).

P.S. A commuting family of endomorphisms actually forms an Abelian (therefore nilpotent) Lie subalgebra of `End K V` and so the above lemma actually follows from [https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Lie/Weights/Basic.html#LieModule.iSup_genWeightSpace_eq_top](LieModule.iSup_genWeightSpace_eq_top). Likewise independence. However having briefly tried this approach, I don't advocate it --- not least for the dependence it would create on Lie theory.

This is very cool! I'm looking forward to seeing how this turns out. Thanks, @ocfnash for looking over the PR!

I realised that I should have proved the relevant result in Lie theory in a more general setting so I've opened #17194 to implement this.

The headline result is the lemma `Module.End.iSup_iInf_maxGenEigenspace_eq_top_of_commute`. Note that it only assumes `(h : ‚àÄ i j œÜ, MapsTo (f i) ((f j).maxGenEigenspace œÜ) ((f j).maxGenEigenspace œÜ))`, i.e., that the family of maps preserve each others' generalised eigenspaces. This is true for commuting families of maps but is a strictly weaker assumption (and this is useful, e.g., where I apply it to nilpotent but not necessarily Abelian Lie algebras).

So if this is merged and you prove that for symemtric operators, generalised eigenspaces are just eigenspaces, then the only remaining work will be to establish independence. A similar generalisation of [LieModule.independent_genWeightSpace](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Lie/Weights/Basic.html#LieModule.independent_genWeightSpace) should work for this. I think this will be slightly easier than what I've done in #17194 but I won't have time to do it in the near future.

Thanks for the heads up, Oliver! Jireh already has the result identifying
gen eigenspaces with eigenspaces, so we can try to finish this up. Thanks for
working on this!

Thanks for this.

I have some concerns about whether these results are being developed at the right level of generality. I have highlighted two results which work for any generalised eigenspace, not just the strict eigenspace (`k = 1` case). This is how I would clean this up a bit:

1. use `isEmpty_or_nonempty` instead of `by_cases`; often the bespoke `‚à®` statements are nicer than using `by_cases` because you don't have to `simp` the negation through the statement.
2. No need to give a name to `i`.
3. using `exists_pair_ne` is overkill because you don't need `w` at all, so using `Classical.arbitrary` to get `i` works.
4. Instead of `have D`, you can just `specialize H`, and that prevents cluttering the infoview.
5. Instead of `have G` and later `rw [‚Üê G] at H`, you can just do `conv at H` to rewrite  `H` on the spot.
6. By pulling the `rw [‚Üê (Equiv.funSplitAt i ùïú).symm.iSup_comp, iSup_prod, iSup_comm]` out into the main proof, we get that `H` and `‚ä¢` match very closely, so applying `convert` is nice, and it can simultaneously introduce variables for us.
7. As I predicted above, we don't actually need the earlier lemma `invariant_submodule_inf_eigenspace`.

Note: doing it this way exposed an API hole: we don't have a `genEigenspace_one` lemma.

This lemma should live in `LinearAlgebra.EigenSpace.Basic`. Furthermore, if only for consistency, it should follow the patterns there so that:

- it should use the language of `Set.MapsTo`
- it should be generalised to any generalised eigenspace (not just the `k = 1` case)
- it should spell the commutation condition using `Commute`

I also think this will be easier to work with if we avoid using `Subtype.restrict` and instead use `iInf` to control the input. 

I thus suggest something like:
```suggestion
lemma mapsTo_iInf_genEigenspace_of_forall_comm
    {T : n ‚Üí Module.End R E} (hC : Pairwise fun i j ‚Ü¶ Commute (T i) (T j))
    (i : n) (Œº : {x // x ‚â† i} ‚Üí R) (k : ‚Ñï) :
    MapsTo (T i)
      (‚®Ö j : {j // j ‚â† i}, genEigenspace (T j) (Œº j) k)
      (‚®Ö j : {j // j ‚â† i}, genEigenspace (T j) (Œº j) k) := by
  intro v hv
  simp only [Set.iInf_eq_iInter, Set.mem_iInter, SetLike.mem_coe, Subtype.forall] at hv ‚ä¢
  intro j hj
  exact mapsTo_genEigenspace_of_comm (hC hj) (Œº ‚ü®j, hj‚ü©) k (hv j hj)
```
We could also write `(‚®Ö (j) (hj : j ‚â† i), genEigenspace (T j) (Œº ‚ü®j, hj‚ü©) k)` instead of `(‚®Ö j : {j // j ‚â† i}, genEigenspace (T j) (Œº j) k)` above but I think what I have proposed is probably the most useful spelling.

One final remark, it might be worth considering changing the type of `Œº` to `Œº : n ‚Üí R` even though its value at `i` is irrelevant. My _guess_ is that most users will have a `Œº` of this type and those that don't should still be able to use this lemma by cooking up a junk value. Furthermore, it results in a much simpler statement.

```lean
    exact Submodule.inf_orthogonal_eq_bot p
  ¬∑ rw [codisjoint_iff]
    have : FiniteDimensional ùïú E := sorry -- Can avoid I presume
    apply Submodule.sup_orthogonal_of_completeSpace -- Overkill I think
```
OK. Will work on this a bit.
In infinite dimensions, you do seem to need that a subspace `K` is closed in order for `K` perp and `K` to span the space...so I don't think what you have there is overkill...

@ocfnash I'm not sure why completeness is overkill here (although finite dimensionality is, but we run into the problem that [FiniteDimensional.complete](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Algebra/Module/FiniteDimension.html#FiniteDimensional.complete) is not an instance, which is slightly annoying whenever it comes up). And `T := LinearMap.id` is symmetric. Moreover, it is semisimple if and only if every subspace (not necessarily *closed*!) is complemented. I think this isn't true for inner product spaces that are not complete.

> It isn't true if the space isn't complete.

In that case, just assume completeness. When users call this lemma, they can invoke the [FiniteDimensional.complete](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Algebra/Module/FiniteDimension.html#FiniteDimensional.complete) lemma if necessary.

I should have been more precise. To get the semisimplicity here we need that all subspaces are complete, since we want them all to be orthogonally complemented. This requires the space to be finite dimensional...or otherwise there are going to be non-closed subspaces around...
For this reason, though, we probably want to keep those other results, as well...because this one only holds in finite dimensions...

Yes, I was in a hurry earlier (about to start work): of course you need some assumption because in general there will be non-closed invariant subspaces, or else you need to adjust the conclusion. One idea I had in mind as I was writing this were that one could consider introducing a "semisimple on finite-dimensional subspaces" definition. This is weaker than `IsSemisimple` and is satisfied here and I think should still be enough for `IsSemisimple.maxGenEigenspace_eq_eigenspace` to hold. I'm not sure if I really like this idea though.

Annoyingly I'm still under time pressure so I can't think properly about this till later this evening.

The other thing I did earlier was to put together https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17654

This is the other half of item 3 in [my comment here](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16569#issuecomment-2372447382) where I said "(and a similar statement for independence)".

If this is merged, then we will know that the simultaneous maximum generalised eigenspaces of any family of endomorphims in finite dimensions (over any field) decompose the space as a direct sum.

Pursuing the approach not to specialise the coefficients prematurely, the next thing to do would be to prove the independent result that if the members of the family are self-adjoint (in the sense of [LinearMap.IsSelfAdjoint](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/LinearAlgebra/SesquilinearForm.html#LinearMap.IsSelfAdjoint)) wrt a non-degenerate bilinear form then generalised eigenspaces are eigenspaces.

And then that's it really (all just algebra) except a very short lemma in the analysis corner of the library which restates the final conclusion over an inner-product space.

> the simultaneous maximum generalised eigenspaces of any family of endomorphims in finite dimensions (over any field) decompose the space as a direct sum.

I think this requires that the characteristic polynomials all split (or else that the field is algebraically closed). Indeed, generalized eigenvalues are eigenvalues, so this is necessary.
@ocfnash : This is now touching a lot of files. Would it be ok to pursue these latest ideas in another PR?

I'll let Jireh make the call here. I don't think the number of files is large (currently it's 5, and could easily be 3).

The only point about which I feel somewhat strongly is that we should not be proving results with the assumptions of `‚Ñù` or `‚ÑÇ` when they are true for any field.

However, again, I'll leave this in Jireh's hands.
Let me talk to Jireh about it @ocfnash. I guess you guys intend to add an assumption about the splitting of the charpoly, and that would do it...let's see what he says.

or `orthogonalComplement_invariant`
```suggestion
lemma orthogonalComplement_le_comap_self {T : E ‚Üí‚Çó[ùïú] E} (hT : T.IsSymmetric) {p : Submodule ùïú E}
    (hp : p ‚â§ Submodule.comap T p) : p·óÆ ‚â§ Submodule.comap T p·óÆ := by
```

The point of Oliver's previous comment:

> Bearing in mind [Module.End.IsSemisimple.genEigenspace_eq_eigenspace](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/LinearAlgebra/Eigenspace/Semisimple.html#Module.End.IsSemisimple.genEigenspace_eq_eigenspace) and [Module.End.IsSemisimple.maxGenEigenspace_eq_eigenspace](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/LinearAlgebra/Eigenspace/Semisimple.html#Module.End.IsSemisimple.maxGenEigenspace_eq_eigenspace) I wonder if instead of these we could prove ...

is that we don't need these anymore given the proof of `LinearMap.IsSymmetric.isSemisimple` that you gave elsewhere.
```suggestion
```

Yes, but these don't require the finite dimensional assumption, so I thought they might be useful elsewhere later because they are hence more general. (I figured the idea was to use as general results as possible for as long as possible. Please disabuse me of this notion if it isn't right!)

IMHO the right solution for me to complete #17689 where I introduce the "semisimple on finite-dimensional subspaces" property (which holds for symmetric infinite-dimensional operators) and where I also prove that for any operators satisfying this condition, all generalised eigenvectors are true eigenvectors.

To avoid being blocked by my work, I suggest you follow Jireh's advice and do not add these lemmas, but retain the fact that we have semisimplicity in finite dimensions. I can generalise this to finitely semisimple in all dimensions later on.

```suggestion
    exact Submodule.sup_orthogonal_of_completeSpace
```

```suggestion
theorem genEigenspace_one_eq_eigenspace {f : End R M} {Œº : R} :
```

This suggests to me that this is the wrong file for that `Semisimple` result‚Äå. I think it should be possible to put it in `Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.Projection` with `Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.Semisimple` as the only new import there.
Ok cool. Will do that. This is a nice way to spot such a thing, too...

pullRequest.title: feat(Analysis.InnerProductSpace): Decomposition of finite-dimensional inner product space as direct sum of joint eigenspaces of commuting finite tuples of symmetric operators

I have some concerns about whether these results are being developed at the right level of generality. I have highlighted two results which work for any generalised eigenspace, not just the strict eigenspace (`k = 1` case). I am also a bit surprised that my changes proposed in #16915 have not been implemented (even though that PR was closed on this promise üò±)

I also wonder what other results might be split out which are true for coefficients other than `‚Ñù` or `‚ÑÇ`.

Unfortunately I don't have more time to give to this at the moment but I encourage you to think carefully about these points: it's sometimes a lot more work but I think we all benefit hugely from working more generally where this is possible.

I thought a little more about this and here are my thoughts.

1. I'd probably first prove the result that for symmetric operators, (maximal) generalised eigenspaces and true eigenspaces are the same thing.

2. I claim it is usually better to work within the lattice of submodules and so I think rather than proving a headline result in the language of `DirectSum.IsInternal` I'd prove the equivalent pair of conditions according to [DirectSum.isInternal_submodule_iff_independent_and_iSup_eq_top](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/DirectSum/Module.html#DirectSum.isInternal_submodule_iff_independent_and_iSup_eq_top) [Feel free to disagree with me here; I mention this primarily because I use this language below]

3. I think the right level of generality is to prove the following first:
```lean
open Module in
lemma iSup_iInf_maxGenEigenspace_eq_top_of_commute {Œπ K V : Type*}
    [Field K] [AddCommGroup V] [Module K V] [FiniteDimensional K V]
    (f : Œπ ‚Üí End K V)
    (h : Pairwise fun i j ‚Ü¶ Commute (f i) (f j))
    (h' : ‚àÄ i, ‚®Ü Œº, (f i).maxGenEigenspace Œº = ‚ä§) :
    ‚®Ü œá : Œπ ‚Üí K, ‚®Ö i, (f i).maxGenEigenspace (œá i) = ‚ä§ := by
sorry
```
(and a similar statement for independence)

4. Assuming I've got the above right, combining 1 and 3 should give you what you need for symmetric operators in the more restrictive setting of an `InnerProductSpace` (with coeffs in `‚Ñù` or `‚ÑÇ`).

P.S. A commuting family of endomorphisms actually forms an Abelian (therefore nilpotent) Lie subalgebra of `End K V` and so the above lemma actually follows from [https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Lie/Weights/Basic.html#LieModule.iSup_genWeightSpace_eq_top](LieModule.iSup_genWeightSpace_eq_top). Likewise independence. However having briefly tried this approach, I don't advocate it --- not least for the dependence it would create on Lie theory.

This is very cool! I'm looking forward to seeing how this turns out. Thanks, @ocfnash for looking over the PR!

I realised that I should have proved the relevant result in Lie theory in a more general setting so I've opened #17194 to implement this.

The headline result is the lemma `Module.End.iSup_iInf_maxGenEigenspace_eq_top_of_commute`. Note that it only assumes `(h : ‚àÄ i j œÜ, MapsTo (f i) ((f j).maxGenEigenspace œÜ) ((f j).maxGenEigenspace œÜ))`, i.e., that the family of maps preserve each others' generalised eigenspaces. This is true for commuting families of maps but is a strictly weaker assumption (and this is useful, e.g., where I apply it to nilpotent but not necessarily Abelian Lie algebras).

So if this is merged and you prove that for symemtric operators, generalised eigenspaces are just eigenspaces, then the only remaining work will be to establish independence. A similar generalisation of [LieModule.independent_genWeightSpace](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Lie/Weights/Basic.html#LieModule.independent_genWeightSpace) should work for this. I think this will be slightly easier than what I've done in #17194 but I won't have time to do it in the near future.

working on this!
